questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with 2 months of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. On ultrasound examination, all of the following are assessed except ______.
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid volume is assessed on ultrasound in the second and third trimesters.

Ultrasonographic evaluation during the first trimester includes:

  • Gestational sac size, location, and number
  • Embryo and/or yolk sac identification
  • Crown-rump length
  • Fetal number, including amnionicity and chorionicity of multifetal gestations
  • Embryonic/fetal cardiac activity
  • Maternal uterus, adnexa, and cul-de-sac
  • Fetal nuchal translucency.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic for the first time at 18 weeks of amenorrhea. She does not remember her LMP and no ultrasound scans were done in the first trimester. In this situation, gestational age can be most accurately estimated by which of the following parameters?
questions.solution:
In the second trimester, the parameter to assess gestational age most accurately is the biparietal diameter (BPD). Accuracy varies from 7 to 10 days. 

BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner edge of the skull in the far field. 

Trimester Parameter
First Crown rump length (CRL)
Second  Biparietal diameter (BPD)
Third  Femur length (FL)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with complaints of 7 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. Her ultrasound scan is shown below. What does the red arrowhead represent?
questions.solution:
The red arrowhead represents the yolk sac. The yellow arrowhead shows the double ring - outer decidua parietalis and inner decidua capsularis. 

It is referred to as the double decidua sign and is seen in the first trimester transvaginal sonogram. It is useful to confirm an early intrauterine location for the pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Head circumference is measured from which of the following ultrasonographic views?
questions.solution:
Head circumference (HC) is measured from the transthalamic view by placing an ellipse around the outer edge of the skull

HC can also be calculated from the biparietal diameter (BPD) and occipital-frontal diameter (OFD).

questions.text: What is the normal range of femur length to abdominal circumference ratio?
questions.solution:
The normal range for the femoral length (FL) to abdominal circumference (AC) ratio is 20-24 percent.

Low FL/AC (< 16) ratio suggests a lethal skeletal dysplasia, particularly if other skeletal abnormalities are present.

questions.text: A woman presents at 33-weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery Doppler imaging shows the following finding. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts reversal of end-diastolic flow or REDF (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. As the period of gestation has exceeded 32 weeks, the pregnancy can be terminated. 

In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but don't appear below it. This suggests a fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >34 weeks.

Reversed end-diastolic flow (REDF) suggests impending fetal death, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the first-trimester ultrasound?

choices.text: A gestational sac can first be seen 4 weeks after LMP
Accuracy of USG dating decreases after the 1st trimester
Yolk sac is the first sign of pregnancy on USG
A normal gestational sac implants in the midline of the endometrial cavity

questions.solution:
The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound is the highest in the first trimester and decreases afterwards.

Option A: Gestational sac is reliably seen at 5 weeks of gestation on transvaginal sonography(TVS).

Option C: The first sign of pregnancy seen on sonography is the gestational sac. Visualisation of the yolk sac within the gestational sac confirms an intrauterine location for pregnancy. 

Option D: A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium, whereas a pseudosac is seen in the midline of the endometrial cavity.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation?
questions.solution:
Nuchal translucency evaluation, a component of first-trimester aneuploidy screening, is done between 11-14 weeks.

It represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue, overlying the fetal spine, at the back of the neck. When the nuchal translucency is increased, the risk of fetal aneuploidy and structural anomalies such as heart defects is significantly elevated.

First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes and a sonographic measurement:

  1. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  2. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)
  3. Nuchal translucency (NT)

It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum-free β-hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.

Note: Nuchal fold is a normal fold of skin seen at the back of the fetal neck during the second trimester of pregnancy. Increased nuchal fold thickness is associated with fetal aneuploidy.

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text:
Which of the following are sonographic markers for Down's syndrome?
  1. Increased nuchal thickness
  2. Echogenic bowel
  3. Pyelectasis
  4. Mild ventricular dilation
  5. Increased femur length
questions.solution:
Ultrasound markers for Down's syndrome:

  • First trimester
    • Nuchal translucency >3 mm
  • Second trimester
    • Echogenic intracardiac focus
    • Ventriculomegaly
    • Nuchal thickness >6 mm
    • Echogenic bowel
    • Hypoplastic/absent nasal bone
    • Shortened humerus, femur
    • Mild pylectasis
    • Aberrant subclavian artery.

questions.text: The anomaly scan of a G3A2 woman is given below. Identify the sign.
questions.solution:
The given image shows banana sign.

An abnormal anterior curvature of cerebellum along with effacement of cisterna magna produces this appearance. It is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation.

Lemon sign: Axial USG image of the fetal head at the level of the biparietal diameter shows inward concavity of both frontal bones instead of the normally seen convexity. This gives the head the appearance of a lemon. It has a strong association with spina bifida and is very useful for detecting this condition.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following USG finding is seen. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows an open defect in the calvaria and skin leading to the exposure of the cranial neural tube. This is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly. 

Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.  Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly. 

  • Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 
  • Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.

Neural-tube defects can be prevented with pre-conceptional supplementation of folic acid. A dose of 4 mg daily is recommended in subsequent pregnancies.  

The frog eye and showercap signs are shown below:

 

Option B: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

 

Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. The images below show the MRI and USG appearance of cystic hygroma, respectively:

 

Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. 

The image shows a newborn with encephalocele.

Robert's sign is a gas shadow in the fetal heart. It is seen in fetal demise in utero and may appear as early as 12 hours.

Other sonographic signs seen in fetal demise in utero are:

  • Absent fetal heartbeat
  • Absent fetal movements
  • Occasional findings
    • Overlapping of skull bones - Spalding's sign 
    • Gross distortion of fetal anatomy (maceration)
    • Soft tissue edema - skin >5 mm
    • Echogenic amniotic fluid  (fetal demise fragments)
  • Uncommon findings
    • Thrombus in fetal heart
    • Gas shadow in the fetal heart - Robert's sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: What is the frequency of a transabdominal transducer?
questions.solution:
The frequency of trans abdominal transducer is 4-6 megahertz (MHz) since a lower frequency penetrates better.

On the other hand, a vaginal transducer has a frequency of 5-10 megahertz since a higher frequency yields a better image with minimal penetration.

questions.text: When is fetal cardiac activity first detected on transabdominal USG?
questions.solution:
The cardiac activity of the fetus is first detected on transabdominal USG (TAS) at the 6th week of intrauterine life.

Fetal structure

TVS

(weeks)

TAS

(weeks)

Gestational sac

4.5

5.5

Yolk sac

5

6

Cardiac activity

6 - 6.5

6 - 7

questions.text: A pregnant woman has her first antenatal visit in the 8th month of gestation. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 30 weeks and the fetal heart rate is 136/min. What is the best parameter for the estimation of fetal age by USG in this patient?
questions.solution:
Femur length is the best parameter for the estimation of fetal age by USG in the 3rd trimester. 

Best USG parameters for estimation of fetal age:

Trimester

Parameter

First

Crown-rump length (CRL)

Second

Biparietal diameter (BPD)

Third

Femur length (FL)

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding sonography in pregnancy?

choices.text: All machines must display thermal index
Tissue heating is higher with shorter examination time
Risks are greater during organogenesis than later in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Tissue heating is higher with longer examination time.

Sonography should be performed in compliance with the ALARA principle which is As Low As Reasonably Achievable. The theoretical risks are greater during organogenesis (8-15 weeks) than later in pregnancy. 

All sonography machines must display 2 indices - the thermal index and the mechanical index.

questions.text: A pregnant diabetic woman presents for a routine antenatal visit during the third trimester. During the evaluation, you perform obstetrical Doppler imaging. Which among the following would indicate fetal compromise?

choices.text: Increased pulsatalilty index in umbilical artery

questions.solution:
Absent end diastolic flow indicates fetal compromise in Doppler.

Umbilical artery vessels:

  • They are characterized by forward low-resistance flow.
  • As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases.
  • S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Abnormal flow patterns in umbilical artery:

  • Reduced end-diastolic flow - Uteroplacental insufficiency (systolic/diastolic ratio increases)
  • Absent end-diastolic flow - Fetal compromise (hence pregnancy is terminated by cesarean section if >34 weeks)
  • Reverse end-diastolic flow - Impending death (pregnancy is terminated irrespective of gestational age)

Doppler of the middle cerebral artery helps in detecting fetal anemia. Increased fetal diastolic flow in the middle cerebral artery with absent diastolic flow in the aorta implies fetal acidemia.
